The suggestion to evaluate teams rather than individuals is intriguing. I’m curious what this could look like in practice. Restructuring departments into teams might work for some, but reduce breadth for teaching too much for others. How might distributed teams be “assessed”?

I especially resonate with their argument that ‘ignoring indirect effects hinders the efficient division of labor that is crucial for “large team” science’. A concern about the @PsySciAcc is that this model might not work for members unless their indirect efforts are recognised.

👍📝 Ignoring indirect effects:

1. fails to reward scientists who help others and fails to penalize scientists who harm others

2. increases the intensity of competition between individual scientists

3. reduces the incentive to specialize in unique skills that complement others https://t.co/5vQrSSqpgK

KHR: Scientists should get behind the student debt cancellation movement; stressed scientists with precarious jobs do "safe" science (I'd add it also reduces diversity in science)

What is the most important skill young scientists should learn?

KHR: reflexivity
SL: transdisciplinarity (not in opposition to specialization)
IF: reflexivity, especially for quant psychs; psych needs theoreticians
BD: awareness/questioning of assumptions

KHR: country- vs discpline-specific preprint servers, can they function as a source of exploitation?

SL: any infrastructure can lead to exploitation; country-specific preprints can benefit researchers if they provide translation to English

General discussion: Is efficiency a useful value to have in science? 

DP: efficiency is easy to measure, but not most valuable
SL: how do we define successful science?
IF: efficiency ties to funding and incentives

Sadly, I have a hard time comprehending talks without slides and my neighbour is playing the trumpet loudly, so my notes are rubbish for this.

Capitalism is the Thing
There is racist work on preprint servers (and in journals!) 
Some bad covid preprints (quickly debunked)
The final presentation is by Kyle Harp-Rushing, who did an ethnographic study of the Center for Open Science https://t.co/FHBGxjudvZ

Concludes that a transparent meta-methodology needs to

1. de-prioritise arbitrary goal posts
2. focus on facts, not bare assertions
3. aim for higher precision, nuance, and statistical rigor
(My perspective may be different, but I see a lot of focus on the latter issues in methods reform, especially in the mixed models area.)

Argues that science reform has prioritised sample size, p-hacking, restricting data use, replication studies, and transparency in empirical claims over sampling issues, model misspecification, visually studying data, theory development, and transparency in meta-methods.

Replication cannot always demarcate between truth and falsehood. False results can be highly reproducible and true results can have low reproducibility (e.g., when power is low) https://t.co/wy5kuX4c11

An idealised study is a function of the assumed model, model unknowns, random sample of size n, methods (design and analysis), background knowledge, and decision rules

A replication study differs in the random sample and background knowledge adds knowledge of the original study
https://t.co/bEmtBQHtEA

Common asserions in science reform:

1. Science should strive to improve replicability/results reproducibility
2. Replication is the way to separate true findings from false positives
3. True results are reproducible
Next is @zerdeve on formal methodology in scientific reform with a quote that encapsulates her key argument. https://t.co/OTCVINktXt

Concludes with a great question about the extent to which "metascience" implies a unitary science. The first question is also about how metascience is discipline-specific. Links to @SabinaLeonelli's points about sources of epistemic diversity.
Metascience can be perceived as a causing "bureaucratic creep", especially when the reasons for new policies are not well understood or co-opted by management.
Argues that metascience has become institutionalised. Funders have now taken notice. The rhetoric has changed from crisis to increased efficiency.

The three strands of metascience:

1. Open Science Activism - borne out of library science
2. Science of Science - big data, moving from observational to experimental science
3. Methodological/statistical criticism - long history, but rapid recent development https://t.co/39PZWFwZlU
Introduces the idea of a Scientific/Intellectual Social Movement (SIM) https://t.co/Y38pr5JmzJ

Views of the replication crisis:

Psychologically, scientists are biased.
Sociologically, scientists respond to incentives.
Philosophically, truth emerges statistically from data.

Next is David Peterson on Metascience as a social movement

https://t.co/nXdhMZcV83
@BeccaEHarrison Wow! When did they stop including the charger?

Local variability in systems of research assessment, values, research capacity, infrastructure, funding, career stage, power dynamics, and researcher demographics can all result in epistemic diversity.
The project described at https://t.co/KBPxhTuUWj identified some key challenges https://t.co/w8CRnFI2Yb

After outlining a large number of problems with science, including diversity, incentives, and accountability, the next slide asks, "Open Science: A Solution?" I wonder if it makes any sense to expect one solution to all those problems.
Up next is @SabinaLeonelli on the scientific and social implications of implementing open science policies and procedures.

Re: theory formalisation: Do different subfields of psychology have different capacity to formalise theory? It's telling that many in the "prereg skeptics" group are computational or mathematical psychologists, while many of the "rep refs" are cognitive or social psychologists.

Final questions:

What is the capacity of psychological science at large to employ theory formalisation?

Will mainstream reform stop centering replication and move to theory?

Replicationist reformers attacked the myth of self-correction, focusing on methods for correcting the literature such as replication & preregistration

Preregistration skeptics attacked the myth of self-organisation, focusing on theory and reform outside the literature

3 scientific identities:

Status-quo psychologists - scientific lit is self-correcting
 
Replicationist reformers - lit needs to be continuously corrected

Preregistration skeptics - lit needs to be organised around a body of theory to benefit from robust hypothesis testing

@drboothroyd Would you be happy with whatever padding I wanted to default to or would you want the ability to control it more finely?

Alternatively, I could use syntax more like ggplot, where you can set the x and y coordinates for the text anchor and use hjust and vjust to align the text anchor to the text. (e.g., hjust = 1, vjust = 0.5 sets the text anchor to the right edge of the text in the vertical centre)

@richarddmorey @annemscheel @siminevazire @SchulteMi @AndyPerfors I don’t get how 1-tailed tests write results out of the process. But I could be misinterpreting you. 

If your H is y>x and you use a 1-tailed test, if x>>y, you conclude that your H was wrong and that y!>x, you don’t conclude that y==x.

@AndyPerfors @richarddmorey What do you mean by “your decision”? If it’s whether or not your data are consistent with a directional hypothesis, then the decision is identical in the case of a null result and a significant result opposite to predictions, right?

@siminevazire @SchulteMi @annemscheel @AndyPerfors I agree and think we should do a lot less hypothesis testing and a lot more estimation. I guess I’m just not sure how 2-sided tests for directional hypotheses help us do that. It’s like a sneaky way to conditionally add another hypothesis.

@siminevazire @SchulteMi @annemscheel @AndyPerfors This might be definitional. I see a *hypothesis* as a speculation about how something works, and e.g. y>0 is a *prediction* from the H. So if y<0, that’s inconsistent with my H, but doesn’t mean I have to conclude y=0. It’s now just an observation used to form a new H.

@siminevazire @SchulteMi @annemscheel @AndyPerfors But *relative to your original hypothesis*, isn’t a result in the opposite direction to predicted interpreted exactly the same as a null? It’s only interpretable otherwise in light of HARKing, or am I misunderstanding something?
@EstherPapies I’m so excited! It’s my first vote in Scotland after 17 years here and my first in-person vote ever! (I postal voted at uni then moved away from the US in 2000)

@itjohnstone @richarddmorey @AndyPerfors Yeah, what exactly are you meant to conclude about a 2-sided test that is significant in the opposite direction to the prediction from the hypothesis you’re testing? Is that basically treating a 2-tailed test like TOST with an SESOI of 0?

@wfrankenhuis1 Very. It’s part of why @lakens and I started developing a way to formalise your decision process for hypotheses. It won’t stop some types of retrofitting theories, but makes it clear what patterns of results an author thinks do or don’t support their idea.

In conclusion:

* Identify the skills you want students to learn
* Identify the tools and assignments that let you teach that
* Integrate new skills into teaching, research and admin
* Everyone benefits from teaching based around reproducible methods
Contrary to fears, the students don't hate it (any more than they hated SPSS) and most really see the value in this teaching approach. https://t.co/njGw1Tc2eS
Coding is a great graduate skill for postgraduate work and non-academic employability. We have several graduates working in data sciences now, like @MandyNorrbo @VickyLeigh_

Our PGR students developed a workshop to teach data visualisation in R to social sciences students @beautiful_hack 
https://t.co/vnaOEFAKb4

Our postgraduate teaching assistants are amazing. Their best advice is "Don't touch the keyboard!" (which is less of a problem now with Zoom teaching :) but students learn more if you talk through the problem and let them type the code.
@DrGBuckingham @McAleerP @Project_TIER @UofGPsychology The talk is at the link above (pre-recorded), but I'm not sure if the discussion is recorded.
Engaging with preprints (@OSFramework), preregistrations (@OSFPrereg), open peer review (@CollabraOA), and team science(@CREP_psych, @PsySciAcc) also embeds open science values in methods curriculum.

Methods curriculum reform isn't just coding. We've integrated reproducibility into essays and research assignments, such as using open access peer-reviews and pre-printed submissions to improve students’ comprehension of academic writing.

https://t.co/j0bIbi8E7A

Staff have to learn new skills, but these skills can help their research and even admin. For example, we've developed an R package to create individual feedback documents and marking summaries from flexibly organised spreadsheets and other types of input.
https://t.co/vSAa84xBCH

Teaching data skills means you need to slow down. The first year focuses on data wrangling, basic of coding, visualisation, and descriptive stats. They start inferential stats in years 2 with a good understanding of data. https://t.co/EHSiBr3Pd3

#psyTeachR books (written in R using bookdown) use the webex package to allow students to self-assess their understanding. 
https://t.co/H5IsNVUelG

When students could choose, test anxiety was lower and competency higher in students who chose to use R (although potentially anxious students may opt for the option perceived as easier).
https://t.co/FXZEH4RRwz https://t.co/T6Esnb4qWN
A great representation of the data processing steps that tend to be hidden in traditional methods teaching (originally from @dalejbarr & featured in the talk above). https://t.co/e0BWhmbORb

@bmwiernik Does this make sense?

Increases with morph distance:
- strong negative exponential: AE, PAE
- slight negative exponential: Fuzz, RMSE
- linear: MAE, MEPP, MSE
- no idea: PHASH

 Decreases with morph distance:
 - linear: NCC, Undefined
- slight exponential decay: PSNR

Undefined: ?
AE: Absolute Error
Fuzz: ?
MAE: Mean Absolute Error
MEPP: Mean Error Per Pixel
MSE: Mean Squared Error
NCC: Normalized Cross Correlation
PAE: Peak Absolute Error
PHASH: Perceptual Hash
PSNR: Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio
RMSE: Root Mean Squared Error

I have fully forgotten the words to verbally describe what is happening with PAE vs PSNR. They are "exponentially curvy in opposite directions", but I definitely can't write that in my documentation and googling "how to describe curves" doesn't help. Any suggestions?

80s style face stimuli with the "standard oval mask"

faces("london")[1:10] %>%
  greyscale() %>%
  pt_delete(frl_features("halo", "neck", "ears")) %>%
  align(procrustes = TRUE) %>%
  oval_mask(fill = "grey") %>%

Or you can set the bounds manually.

bounds = list(t= 50, r = 50, b = 50, l = 50)
oval_mask(stimuli, bounds, "dodgerblue") https://t.co/miBr8tMfOf

You can remove the external features, crop to a standard size with 25 pixels around the max and min template points, and mask.

stimuli %>%
  pt_delete(frl_features("halo", "neck", "ears")) %>%
  crop_pad(25) %>%
  oval_mask() https://t.co/cNjtESw3Mc

> Say you have 3 images (img) and blur is a 3-item vector. What would you call the 3rd arg?

# i1b1, i1b2, i1b3, i2b1, i2b2, i2b3, i3b1, i3b2, i3b3
f(img, blur, "crossed")

# i1b1, i2b2, i3b3
f(img, blur, "each")

# i1, i2, i3 (blur coincidentally length=3)
